'''''Unfinished Tales of Númenor and Middle-earth''''' (often referred to
column3: as just '''''Unfinished Tales''''') is a collection of stories by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] that were never completed during his lifetime
column4: but were edited by his son [[Christopher Tolkien]] and published in 1980.

column2: for which the narrative fragments were modified to connect into a consistent and coherent work
column3: the ''Unfinished Tales'' are presented as Tolkien left them
column4: with little more than names changed (the author having had a confusing habit of trying out different names for a character while writing a draft).  Thus some of these are incomplete stories
column5: while others are collections of "factual" information about [[Middle-earth]]. Each tale is followed by a long series of notes explaining inconsistencies and obscure points.

column2: Christopher Tolkien edited and published ''Unfinished Tales'' before he had finished his study of the materials in his father's archive. Despite its shortcomings in editorial consistency
column3: ''Unfinished Tales'' does provide more detailed information about characters
column4: events and places mentioned only briefly in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''. Versions of such tales including the origins of [[Gandalf]] and the [[Istari]] (Wizards)
column5: the death of [[Isildur]] and the loss of [[the One Ring]] in the [[Gladden Fields]]
column6: and the founding of the kingdom of [[Rohan]] help expand knowledge about Middle-earth.

column1: Of particular note is the tale of [[Tar-Aldarion|Aldarion]] and [[Erendis]]
column2: the only known story of [[Númenor]] before its fall. A map of Númenor is also included in the book.

column1: The commercial success of ''Unfinished Tales'' demonstrated that the demand for Tolkien's stories several years after his death was not only still present
column2: but growing. Encouraged by the result
column3: Christopher Tolkien began to embark upon the more ambitious twelve-volume work entitled ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]'' which encompasses nearly the entire corpus of Tolkien's writings about Middle-earth.
